resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

worklogs.comment:
pitrou commented on pull request #5334: ARROW-6481: [C++] Avoid copying large ConvertOptions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5334
 
 
   If you have N columns and a large subset of them are customized in ConvertOptions,
   copying ConvertOptions in each Converter or ColumnBuilder produces a quadratic
   explosion.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

pitrou commented on issue #5334: ARROW-6481: [C++] Avoid copying large ConvertOptions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5334#issuecomment-529572885
 
 
   Another solution would be to use a `std::shared_ptr<std::unordered_map...`. It will also require adding a non-trivial ConvertOptions constructor that does the allocation. @fsaintjacques what do you think?

fsaintjacques commented on pull request #5334: ARROW-6481: [C++] Avoid copying large ConvertOptions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5334#discussion_r322362262
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/csv/converter.h
 ##########
 @@ -57,7 +57,9 @@ class ARROW_EXPORT Converter {
 
   virtual Status Initialize() = 0;
 
-  const ConvertOptions options_;
+  // CAUTION: ConvertOptions can grow large (if it customizes hundreds or
+  // thousands of columns), so avoid copying it in each Converter.
+  const ConvertOptions& options_;
 
 Review comment:
   I'd say keep this one a value, but let the ColumnBuilder's be reference, since they're component inside the Converter. This would amount to a single copy (which can be moved' by the caller), or none if you move in the constructor.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

fsaintjacques commented on issue #5334: ARROW-6481: [C++] Avoid copying large ConvertOptions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5334#issuecomment-529591067
 
 
   I prefer uniformity in the codebase, so no `shared_ptr<ConvertOptions>`. The solution looks fine since the ConvertOptions is held by BaseTableReader.
   
   I recall reading that std::move support in Python/C++ was troublesome. Making the class non-copy-able will be a pain to pass around.
   
   @bkietz the current PR might also affect JsonReader.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5334#issuecomment-529591383
 
 
   I will still try to make the class non-copyable by default as proposed by @wesm , as it would prevent annoying regressions.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Case: Dataset wit 20k columns. Amount of rows can be 0.

{{pyarrow.csv.read_csv('20k_cols.csv')}} works rather fine if no convert_options provided.

Took 150ms.

Now I call {{read_csv()}} with column types mapping that marks 2000 out of these columns as string.

{{pyarrow.csv.read_csv('20k_cols.csv', convert_options=pyarrow.csv.ConvertOptions(column_types=\{'K%d' % i: pyarrow.string() for i in range(2000)}))}}

(K1..K19999 are column names in attached dataset).

My task globally is to read everything as string, avoid any inferring.

This takes several minutes, consumes around 4GB memory.

This doesn't look sane at all.
fields.summary: [Python][C++] Bad performance of read_csv() with column_types

comments.body: I don't think hashtable lookup on each column has to make it be hundreds of times slower. Worth noting that it works so bad even if dataset has 0 rows, so this performance problem happens on reading column header.
Are you able to take a look to see what might be wrong?
